results.title: Jungle farming
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Describes the cooperative work involved in jungle farming of the Makiritare Indians. Explains that, after the men use the slash and burn technique to clear the jungle away, the women simultaneously harvest and plant manioc roots, pineapples, chillipeppers, bananas and plantations. Living near the equator they can farm all the year round. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Village life
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Introduces the variety of activities in the Makiritare Indian village of Kononama (South America). Women spin cotton, look after babies and chickens, and bathe in the river, while the children draw, wrestle and throw spears. Men weave baskets from sisal for squeezing the poison out of manloc roots and make jewellery for a dance.

results.title: Woodwinds and dance
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
One of a series of films recording the various aspects of daily life among the remote tribes of Indians in the South American jungles. Using large pieces of bamboo, two young men make bassoon like instruments, which are used in a village dance.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Miss Navy
results.creator_credit: Margaret Morton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Margaret Morton’s first time in the navy was short lived, as she contracted pneumonia which further developed into tuberculosis, just six months after joining. This meant Margaret spent an extended period of time hospitalised and in isolation, an experience she found frustrating and lonely. Morton describes the memories she still holds dear from her short time in service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Morton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Knock at the door
results.creator_credit: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: War has followed Helen all her life. As a young girl, she wrote letters to her brothers overseas and she had feared losing her husband in the Vietnam war. That dreaded knock on the door was something she never wanted to hear.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
results.description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: Spuds again
results.brief_description: Irrespresible and cheeky, Avis Quarrell was an avid church goer but liked nothing more than making fun of her superiors. One particular day landed her in hot water and back to peeling spuds.

results.title: A Secret war room
results.creator_credit: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
description_for_label: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
